column2: General Boswell was in his office; a comfortable looking place, with plenty of outline maps hanging about the walls and in the windows, and a spectacled man was marking out another one on a long table.
column3: General Boswell was in his office; a comfortable looking place, with plenty of outline maps hanging about the walls and in the windows, and a spectacled man was marking out another one on a long table.

column2: The office was in the principal street.
column3: The office was in the principal street.

column2: The General received Washington with a kindly but reserved politeness.
column3: The General received Washington with a kindly but reserved politeness.

column2: Washington rather liked his looks.
column3: Washington rather liked his looks.

column2: He was about fifty years old, dignified, well preserved and well dressed. After the Colonel took his leave, the General talked a while with Washington--his talk consisting chiefly of instructions about the clerical duties of the place.
column3: He was about fifty years old, dignified, well preserved and well dressed. After the Colonel took his leave, the General talked a while with Washington-his talk consisting chiefly of instructions about the clerical duties of the place.

column2: He seemed satisfied as to Washington's ability to take care of the books, he was evidently a pretty fair theoretical bookkeeper, and experience would soon harden theory into practice.
column3: He seemed satisfied as to Washington's ability to take care of the books, he was evidently a pretty fair theoretical bookkeeper, and experience would soon harden theory into practice.

column2: By and by dinner-time came, and the two walked to the General's house; and now Washington noticed an instinct in himself that moved him to keep not in the General's rear, exactly, but yet not at his side--somehow the old gentleman's dignity and reserve did not inspire familiarity.
column3: By and by dinner time came, and the two walked to the General's house; and now Washington noticed an instinct in himself that moved him to keep not in the General's rear, exactly, but yet not at his side-somehow the old gentleman's dignity and reserve did not inspire familiarity.

column2: CHAPTER IX.
column3: CHAPTER nine.

column2: Washington dreamed his way along the street, his fancy flitting from grain to hogs, from hogs to banks, from banks to eye-water, from eye-water to Tennessee Land, and lingering but a feverish moment upon each of these fascinations.
column3: Washington dreamed his way along the street, his fancy flitting from grain to hogs, from hogs to banks, from banks to eye water, from eye water to Tennessee Land, and lingering but a feverish moment upon each of these fascinations.

column2: He was conscious of but one outward thing, to wit, the General, and he was really not vividly conscious of him.
column3: He was conscious of but one outward thing, to wit, the General, and he was really not vividly conscious of him.

column2: Arrived at the finest dwelling in the town, they entered it and were at home.
column3: Arrived at the finest dwelling in the town, they entered it and were at home.

column2: Washington was introduced to Mrs. Boswell, and his imagination was on the point of flitting into the vapory realms of speculation again, when a lovely girl of sixteen or seventeen came in.
column3: Washington was introduced to mrs Boswell, and his imagination was on the point of flitting into the vapory realms of speculation again, when a lovely girl of sixteen or seventeen came in.

column2: This vision swept Washington's mind clear of its chaos of glittering rubbish in an instant.
column3: This vision swept Washington's mind clear of its chaos of glittering rubbish in an instant.

column2: Beauty had fascinated him before; many times he had been in love even for weeks at a time with the same object but his heart had never suffered so sudden and so fierce an assault as this, within his recollection.
column3: Beauty had fascinated him before; many times he had been in love even for weeks at a time with the same object but his heart had never suffered so sudden and so fierce an assault as this, within his recollection.

column2: Louise Boswell occupied his mind and drifted among his multiplication tables all the afternoon.
column3: Louise Boswell occupied his mind and drifted among his multiplication tables all the afternoon.

column2: He was constantly catching himself in a reverie--reveries made up of recalling how she looked when she first burst upon him; how her voice thrilled him when she first spoke; how charmed the very air seemed by her presence.
column3: He was constantly catching himself in a reverie-reveries made up of recalling how she looked when she first burst upon him; how her voice thrilled him when she first spoke; how charmed the very air seemed by her presence.

column2: Blissful as the afternoon was, delivered up to such a revel as this, it seemed an eternity, so impatient was he to see the girl again.
column3: Blissful as the afternoon was, delivered up to such a revel as this, it seemed an eternity, so impatient was he to see the girl again.

column2: Other afternoons like it followed.
column3: Other afternoons like it followed.

column2: Washington plunged into this love affair as he plunged into everything else--upon impulse and without reflection.
column3: Washington plunged into this love affair as he plunged into everything else-upon impulse and without reflection.

column2: As the days went by it seemed plain that he was growing in favor with Louise,--not sweepingly so, but yet perceptibly, he fancied.
column3: As the days went by it seemed plain that he was growing in favor with Louise,--not sweepingly so, but yet perceptibly, he fancied.

column2: His attentions to her troubled her father and mother a little, and they warned Louise, without stating particulars or making allusions to any special person, that a girl was sure to make a mistake who allowed herself to marry anybody but a man who could support her well.
column3: His attentions to her troubled her father and mother a little, and they warned Louise, without stating particulars or making allusions to any special person, that a girl was sure to make a mistake who allowed herself to marry anybody but a man who could support her well.

column2: Some instinct taught Washington that his present lack of money would be an obstruction, though possibly not a bar, to his hopes, and straightway his poverty became a torture to him which cast all his former sufferings under that held into the shade.
column3: Some instinct taught Washington that his present lack of money would be an obstruction, though possibly not a bar, to his hopes, and straightway his poverty became a torture to him which cast all his former sufferings under that held into the shade.

column2: He longed for riches now as he had never longed for them before.
column3: He longed for riches now as he had never longed for them before.

column2: He had been once or twice to dine with Col.
column3: He had been once or twice to dine with col

column2: Sellers, and had been discouraged to note that the Colonel's bill of fare was falling off both in quantity and quality--a sign, he feared, that the lacking ingredient in the eye-water still remained undiscovered--though Sellers always explained that these changes in the family diet had been ordered by the doctor, or suggested by some new scientific work the Colonel had stumbled upon.
column3: Sellers, and had been discouraged to note that the Colonel's bill of fare was falling off both in quantity and quality-a sign, he feared, that the lacking ingredient in the eye water still remained undiscovered-though Sellers always explained that these changes in the family diet had been ordered by the doctor, or suggested by some new scientific work the Colonel had stumbled upon.

column2: But it always turned out that the lacking ingredient was still lacking--though it always appeared, at the same time, that the Colonel was right on its heels.
column3: But it always turned out that the lacking ingredient was still lacking-though it always appeared, at the same time, that the Colonel was right on its heels.

column2: Every time the Colonel came into the real estate office Washington's heart bounded and his eyes lighted with hope, but it always turned out that the Colonel was merely on the scent of some vast, undefined landed speculation--although he was customarily able to say that he was nearer to the all-necessary ingredient than ever, and could almost name the hour when success would dawn.
column3: Every time the Colonel came into the real estate office Washington's heart bounded and his eyes lighted with hope, but it always turned out that the Colonel was merely on the scent of some vast, undefined landed speculation-although he was customarily able to say that he was nearer to the all necessary ingredient than ever, and could almost name the hour when success would dawn.

column2: And then Washington's heart would sink again and a sigh would tell when it touched bottom.
column3: And then Washington's heart would sink again and a sigh would tell when it touched bottom.

column2: About this time a letter came, saying that Judge Hawkins had been ailing for a fortnight, and was now considered to be seriously ill.
column3: About this time a letter came, saying that Judge Hawkins had been ailing for a fortnight, and was now considered to be seriously ill.

column2: It was thought best that Washington should come home.
column3: It was thought best that Washington should come home.

column2: The news filled him with grief, for he loved and honored his father; the Boswells were touched by the youth's sorrow, and even the General unbent and said encouraging things to him.--There was balm in this; but when Louise bade him good-bye, and shook his hand and said, "Don't be cast down--it will all come out right--I know it will all come out right," it seemed a blessed thing to be in misfortune, and the tears that welled up to his eyes were the messengers of an adoring and a grateful heart; and when the girl saw them and answering tears came into her own eyes, Washington could hardly contain the excess of happiness that poured into the cavities of his breast that were so lately stored to the roof with grief.
column3: The news filled him with grief, for he loved and honored his father; the Boswells were touched by the youth's sorrow, and even the General unbent and said encouraging things to him.--There was balm in this; but when Louise bade him good bye, and shook his hand and said, "Don't be cast down-it will all come out right-I know it will all come out right," it seemed a blessed thing to be in misfortune, and the tears that welled up to his eyes were the messengers of an adoring and a grateful heart; and when the girl saw them and answering tears came into her own eyes, Washington could hardly contain the excess of happiness that poured into the cavities of his breast that were so lately stored to the roof with grief.

column2: All the way home he nursed his woe and exalted it.
column3: All the way home he nursed his woe and exalted it.

column2: He pictured himself as she must be picturing him: a noble, struggling young spirit persecuted by misfortune, but bravely and patiently waiting in the shadow of a dread calamity and preparing to meet the blow as became one who was all too used to hard fortune and the pitiless buffetings of fate.
column3: He pictured himself as she must be picturing him: a noble, struggling young spirit persecuted by misfortune, but bravely and patiently waiting in the shadow of a dread calamity and preparing to meet the blow as became one who was all too used to hard fortune and the pitiless buffetings of fate.

column2: These thoughts made him weep, and weep more broken-heartedly than ever; and he wished that she could see his sufferings now.
column3: These thoughts made him weep, and weep more broken heartedly than ever; and he wished that she could see his sufferings now.

column2: There was nothing significant in the fact that Louise, dreamy and distraught, stood at her bedroom bureau that night, scribbling "Washington" here and there over a sheet of paper.
column3: There was nothing significant in the fact that Louise, dreamy and distraught, stood at her bedroom bureau that night, scribbling "Washington" here and there over a sheet of paper.

column2: But there was something significant in the fact that she scratched the word out every time she wrote it; examined the erasure critically to see if anybody could guess at what the word had been; then buried it under a maze of obliterating lines; and finally, as if still unsatisfied, burned the paper.
column3: But there was something significant in the fact that she scratched the word out every time she wrote it; examined the erasure critically to see if anybody could guess at what the word had been; then buried it under a maze of obliterating lines; and finally, as if still unsatisfied, burned the paper.

column2: When Washington reached home, he recognized at once how serious his father's case was.
column3: When Washington reached home, he recognized at once how serious his father's case was.

column2: The darkened room, the labored breathing and occasional moanings of the patient, the tip-toeing of the attendants and their whispered consultations, were full of sad meaning.
column3: The darkened room, the labored breathing and occasional moanings of the patient, the tip toeing of the attendants and their whispered consultations, were full of sad meaning.

column2: For three or four nights Mrs. Hawkins and Laura had been watching by the bedside; Clay had arrived, preceding Washington by one day, and he was now added to the corps of watchers.
column3: For three or four nights mrs Hawkins and Laura had been watching by the bedside; Clay had arrived, preceding Washington by one day, and he was now added to the corps of watchers.

column2: Mr. Hawkins would have none but these three, though neighborly assistance was offered by old friends.
column3: mr Hawkins would have none but these three, though neighborly assistance was offered by old friends.

column2: From this time forth three-hour watches were instituted, and day and night the watchers kept their vigils.
column3: From this time forth three hour watches were instituted, and day and night the watchers kept their vigils.

column2: By degrees Laura and her mother began to show wear, but neither of them would yield a minute of their tasks to Clay.
column3: By degrees Laura and her mother began to show wear, but neither of them would yield a minute of their tasks to Clay.

column2: He ventured once to let the midnight hour pass without calling Laura, but he ventured no more; there was that about her rebuke when he tried to explain, that taught him that to let her sleep when she might be ministering to her father's needs, was to rob her of moments that were priceless in her eyes; he perceived that she regarded it as a privilege to watch, not a burden.
column3: He ventured once to let the midnight hour pass without calling Laura, but he ventured no more; there was that about her rebuke when he tried to explain, that taught him that to let her sleep when she might be ministering to her father's needs, was to rob her of moments that were priceless in her eyes; he perceived that she regarded it as a privilege to watch, not a burden.

column2: And, he had noticed, also, that when midnight struck, the patient turned his eyes toward the door, with an expectancy in them which presently grew into a longing but brightened into contentment as soon as the door opened and Laura appeared.
column3: And, he had noticed, also, that when midnight struck, the patient turned his eyes toward the door, with an expectancy in them which presently grew into a longing but brightened into contentment as soon as the door opened and Laura appeared.

column2: And he did not need Laura's rebuke when he heard his father say:
column3: And he did not need Laura's rebuke when he heard his father say:

column2: Clay is good, and you are tired, poor child; but I wanted you so.
column3: Clay is good, and you are tired, poor child; but I wanted you so.

column2: Clay is not good, father--he did not call me.	Clay is not good, father-he did not call me.
column3: true

column2: I would not have treated him so.
column3: I would not have treated him so.

column2: How could you do it, Clay?"
column3: How could you do it, Clay?"

column2: Clay begged forgiveness and promised not to break faith again; and as he betook him to his bed, he said to himself: "It's a steadfast little soul; whoever thinks he is doing the Duchess a kindness by intimating that she is not sufficient for any undertaking she puts her hand to, makes a mistake; and if I did not know it before, I know now that there are surer ways of pleasing her than by trying to lighten her labor when that labor consists in wearing herself out for the sake of a person she loves."
column3: Clay begged forgiveness and promised not to break faith again; and as he betook him to his bed, he said to himself: "It's a steadfast little soul; whoever thinks he is doing the Duchess a kindness by intimating that she is not sufficient for any undertaking she puts her hand to, makes a mistake; and if I did not know it before, I know now that there are surer ways of pleasing her than by trying to lighten her labor when that labor consists in wearing herself out for the sake of a person she loves."

column2: A week drifted by, and all the while the patient sank lower and lower. The night drew on that was to end all suspense.
column3: A week drifted by, and all the while the patient sank lower and lower. The night drew on that was to end all suspense.

column2: It was a wintry one. The darkness gathered, the snow was falling, the wind wailed plaintively about the house or shook it with fitful gusts.
column3: It was a wintry one. The darkness gathered, the snow was falling, the wind wailed plaintively about the house or shook it with fitful gusts.

column2: The doctor had paid his last visit and gone away with that dismal remark to the nearest friend of the family that he "believed there was nothing more that he could do"--a remark which is always overheard by some one it is not meant for and strikes a lingering half-conscious hope dead with a withering shock; the medicine phials had been removed from the bedside and put out of sight, and all things made orderly and meet for the solemn event that was impending; the patient, with closed eyes, lay scarcely breathing; the watchers sat by and wiped the gathering damps from his forehead while the silent tears flowed down their faces; the deep hush was only interrupted by sobs from the children, grouped about the bed.
column3: The doctor had paid his last visit and gone away with that dismal remark to the nearest friend of the family that he "believed there was nothing more that he could do"--a remark which is always overheard by some one it is not meant for and strikes a lingering half conscious hope dead with a withering shock; the medicine phials had been removed from the bedside and put out of sight, and all things made orderly and meet for the solemn event that was impending; the patient, with closed eyes, lay scarcely breathing; the watchers sat by and wiped the gathering damps from his forehead while the silent tears flowed down their faces; the deep hush was only interrupted by sobs from the children, grouped about the bed.

column2: After a time--it was toward midnight now--Mr.
column3: After a time-it was toward midnight now-mr

column2: Hawkins roused out of a doze, looked about him and was evidently trying to speak.
column3: Hawkins roused out of a doze, looked about him and was evidently trying to speak.

column2: Instantly Laura lifted his head and in a failing voice he said, while something of the old light shone in his eyes:
column3: Instantly Laura lifted his head and in a failing voice he said, while something of the old light shone in his eyes:

column2: Wife--children--come nearer--nearer.	Wife-children-come nearer-nearer.
column3: true

column2: The darkness grows.
column3: The darkness grows.

column2: Let me see you all, once more."
column3: Let me see you all, once more."

column2: The group closed together at the bedside, and their tears and sobs came now without restraint.
column3: The group closed together at the bedside, and their tears and sobs came now without restraint.

column2: I am leaving you in cruel poverty.	I am leaving you in cruel poverty.
column3: true

column2: I have been--so foolish--so short-sighted.
column3: I have been-so foolish-so short sighted.

column2: But courage!
column3: But courage!

column2: A better day is--is coming.
column3: A better day is-is coming.

column2: Never lose sight of the Tennessee Land!
column3: Never lose sight of the Tennessee Land!

column2: Be wary.
column3: Be wary.

column2: There is wealth stored up for you there--wealth that is boundless!
column3: There is wealth stored up for you there-wealth that is boundless!

column2: The children shall hold up their heads with the best in the land, yet.
column3: The children shall hold up their heads with the best in the land, yet.

column2: Where are the papers?--Have you got the papers safe?
column3: Where are the papers?--Have you got the papers safe?

column2: Show them--show them to me!"
column3: Show them-show them to me!"

column2: Under his strong excitement his voice had gathered power and his last sentences were spoken with scarcely a perceptible halt or hindrance. With an effort he had raised himself almost without assistance to a sitting posture.
column3: Under his strong excitement his voice had gathered power and his last sentences were spoken with scarcely a perceptible halt or hindrance. With an effort he had raised himself almost without assistance to a sitting posture.

column2: But now the fire faded out of his eyes and he fell back exhausted.
column3: But now the fire faded out of his eyes and he fell back exhausted.

column2: The papers were brought and held before him, and the answering smile that flitted across his face showed that he was satisfied.
column3: The papers were brought and held before him, and the answering smile that flitted across his face showed that he was satisfied.

column2: He closed his eyes, and the signs of approaching dissolution multiplied rapidly.
column3: He closed his eyes, and the signs of approaching dissolution multiplied rapidly.

column2: He lay almost motionless for a little while, then suddenly partly raised his head and looked about him as one who peers into a dim uncertain light.
column3: He lay almost motionless for a little while, then suddenly partly raised his head and looked about him as one who peers into a dim uncertain light.

column2: He muttered:
column3: He muttered:

column2: Gone?	Gone?
column3: true

column2: No--I see you--still.
column3: No-I see you-still.

column2: It is--it is-over.
column3: It is-it is over.

column2: But you are--safe.
column3: But you are-safe.

column2: The voice died out in a whisper; the sentence was never finished.
column3: The voice died out in a whisper; the sentence was never finished.

column2: The emaciated fingers began to pick at the coverlet, a fatal sign.
column3: The emaciated fingers began to pick at the coverlet, a fatal sign.

column2: After a time there were no sounds but the cries of the mourners within and the gusty turmoil of the wind without.
column3: After a time there were no sounds but the cries of the mourners within and the gusty turmoil of the wind without.

column2: Laura had bent down and kissed her father's lips as the spirit left the body; but she did not sob, or utter any ejaculation; her tears flowed silently.
column3: Laura had bent down and kissed her father's lips as the spirit left the body; but she did not sob, or utter any ejaculation; her tears flowed silently.

column2: Then she closed the dead eyes, and crossed the hands upon the breast; after a season, she kissed the forehead reverently, drew the sheet up over the face, and then walked apart and sat down with the look of one who is done with life and has no further interest in its joys and sorrows, its hopes or its ambitions.
column3: Then she closed the dead eyes, and crossed the hands upon the breast; after a season, she kissed the forehead reverently, drew the sheet up over the face, and then walked apart and sat down with the look of one who is done with life and has no further interest in its joys and sorrows, its hopes or its ambitions.

column2: Clay buried his face in the coverlet of the bed; when the other children and the mother realized that death was indeed come at last, they threw themselves into each others' arms and gave way to a frenzy of grief.
column3: Clay buried his face in the coverlet of the bed; when the other children and the mother realized that death was indeed come at last, they threw themselves into each others' arms and gave way to a frenzy of grief.
